newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentine minister rejects Cavallo dishonesty slur.
newsitem.headline: Argentine minister rejects Cavallo dishonesty slur.

text.p: Argentine Economy Minister Roque Fernandez defended his reputation on Tuesday against allegations by his predecessor, Domingo Cavallo, that he is "not capable or not honest."
Cavallo, who is heading a crusade against corruption, lashed out at Fernandez on Monday for describing as "normal" a businessman Cavallo accuses of graft.

Cavallo, fired by President Carlos Menem in July after doing a widely praised job of reforming the Argentine economy, is battling in the courts with Alfredo Yabran, a businessman close to Menem, who he says heads a "mafia" in the customs and postal services. Yabran denies the accusations.

"I have said that Fernandez was a capable and honest man. A capable and honest man does not commit these mistakes. One or the other, or he is not capable or he is not honest," the ex-minister told local television after Fernandez said he believed Yabran was a "normal businessman."

Fernandez, who keeps a low profile and avoids controversy, made a restrained defense. "Since August this year, when President Carlos Menem put me in charge of the Economy Ministry, I have known that what was expected of me was exactly what I know how to do: to work transparently, honestly and hard for Argentina and the Argentine people," he said.
He expressed "shock" in a statement that Cavallo should make such allegations at a time when Argentina is pulling out of a deep recession following Mexico's late-1994 devaluation.
"I am sure the Argentine people will know how to value seriousness and effort above noise that achieves nothing," the Chicago University-trained academic said.
Menem's Peronist government, which includes several senior officials who have also been accused by Cavallo and have threatened to sue him, rallied around Fernandez.

Cabinet Chief Jorge Rodriguez called Cavallo's comments "regrettable" and said: "None of us should try to become the judges of our peers, whether we are in the cabinet or not, because that is what the courts are for."

But Cavallo is not the only ex-minister to accuse Menem's government of graft. Former Interior Minister Gustavo Beliz, once Menem's protege, refused before a judge on Monday to retract comments that Menem had "no credibility" to combat corruption.
